title: EverWatt Energy Efficiency Certification - For Warehouse Engineers
subtitle: Certification for energy efficiency in warehouses and distribution centers
description: Validate your expertise in identifying and implementing energy efficiency measures for warehouses and distribution centers. This certification covers high-bay lighting, minimal HVAC, dock doors, and material handling equipment.

questions.question: In warehouses, what percentage of total energy is typically consumed by lighting?
questions.explanation: Lighting typically consumes 40-60% of total energy in warehouses. This is the largest single end use, making lighting optimization the highest priority for warehouse facilities.

questions.question: A warehouse has 200 high-bay HID fixtures (400W each) operating 16 hours/day. What is the annual energy use?
questions.explanation: 200 fixtures Ã— 400W = 80,000W = 80 kW Ã— 16 hrs/day Ã— 365 days = 467,200 kWh/year. Replacing with LED fixtures (150W each) would reduce to: 200 Ã— 150W = 30 kW Ã— 16 hrs Ã— 365 = 175,200 kWh/year. Savings: 292,000 kWh/year = ~$35,000/year at $0.12/kWh.

questions.question: A warehouse has dock doors that are frequently left open. What is the energy impact?
questions.scenario: A warehouse has 20 dock doors. During loading/unloading operations, doors are frequently left open for extended periods, allowing conditioned air to escape.

options.text: Significant HVAC energy waste, especially in extreme climates

questions.explanation: Open dock doors cause significant HVAC energy waste, especially in extreme climates (hot summers, cold winters). Installing dock door seals, high-speed doors, or dock shelters can reduce this waste. In some cases, minimal HVAC (spot heating/cooling) may be more appropriate than conditioning the entire space.

questions.question: What is the typical energy savings potential for LED high-bay lighting retrofits in warehouses?
questions.explanation: LED high-bay lighting retrofits in warehouses typically yield 50-75% energy savings when replacing HID fixtures. Additional savings (10-40%) can be achieved with controls (scheduling, occupancy, daylight harvesting).

questions.question: What is the typical priority order for energy efficiency measures in warehouses?

options.text: High-Bay Lighting, HVAC (if applicable), Dock Doors, Material Handling
HVAC, Lighting, Building Envelope, Plug Loads
Building Envelope, HVAC, Lighting, Material Handling
Material Handling, Lighting, HVAC, Building Envelope

questions.explanation: For warehouses, High-Bay Lighting is typically Very High priority (40-60% of energy). HVAC is Medium-High priority (if applicable). Dock Doors are Medium-High priority. Material Handling is Medium priority.
